channel.title: Mr Ash Co
channel.description: Recent content on Mr Ash Co

item.title: Creative
item.description: To try SQL Injection (SQLi) Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) <script> alert("XSS");</script> Local File Inclusion (LFI) Remote File Inclusion (RFI) Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) Directory Traversal Command Injection http://example.com/ alert(“XSS”); # Made it hang for a while curl ‘http://beta.creative.thm/' -X HEAD -H ‘Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded’ –data-raw ‘url=""’ curl ‘http://beta.creative.thm/' -I Quick reverse connection test <img src="http://$YOUR_IP/" /> nc -lnvp 80 Thanks for reading

item.title: CyberLens TryHackMe Writeup
item.description: Okay, it’s been a while. Last writeup on the blog is Chill Hack… but she (and other writeups) need a refresher. Anyway, here’s CyberLens, a newish TryHackMe room from Tyler Ramsbey who make’s great content, give them a follow/subscribe. The Challenge First up, the Challenge Description. Welcome to the clandestine world of CyberLens, where shadows dance amidst the digital domain and metadata reveals the secrets that lie concealed within every image.

item.title: Docker
item.description: Let’s learn Docker and set it up. So what’s Docker? Well it’s complicated. It’s a way to install, maintain and run applications. But apps are self-contained, hence the term containers. Docker allows networking and lots more. Installing Docker Best way is to follow the docs. Kali Linux If you’re on Kali Linux, don’t follow the official guide. Go to Installing Docker on Kali Linux from Kali.org instead. sudo apt update sudo apt install -y docker.

item.title: Syncthing
item.description: Let’s install syncthing on Windows. Open Terminal > type winget install synctrayzor. This is a standalone app that just makes using syncthing more user friendly. Synctrayzor should be in your taskbar, click it to open the GUI. Go to Actions > Settings > Connections > Untick ‘Global Discovery’ and ‘Enable Relaying’. Thanks for reading

item.title: Remote Desktop Protocol
item.description: Let’s setup Remote Desktop Protocol on Ubuntu. Start with following this guide. Make sure you’re not logged in as the same user, thanks to this. If you’re using a laptop, thanks to this. sudo nano /etc/systemd/logind.conf HandleSuspendKey=ignore HandleHibernateKey=ignore HandleLidSwitch=ignore HandleLidSwitchExternalPower=ignore HandleLidSwitchDocked=ignore Thanks for reading

item.title: Winget
item.description: How to use winget for Windows 11. What is winget? It’s a package manager for Windows, like choco or apt for debian based linux distros. If that means nothing to you, then it installs and updates apps. Cool? Cool. How to use winget Let’s install syncthing for this example. winget search sync displays a list of matches sync. Name Id Version Match Source -------------------------------------------------------------------- syncthing Syncthing.Syncthing 1.27.0 winget SyncTrayzor SyncTrayzor.SyncTrayzor 1.

item.title: Pi-Hole
item.description: Let’s setup Pi-Hole in Docker, following the official documentation. getconf LONG_BIT check for 32bit or 64bit. cat /etc/os-release check the version of the OS. After following the installation guide, you might receive these errors: E: Package 'docker-ce' has no installation candidate E: Unable to locate package docker-ce-cli E: Unable to locate package containerd.io E: Couldn't find any package by glob 'containerd.io' E: Couldn't find any package by regex 'containerd.io' E: Unable to locate package docker-buildx-plugin E: Unable to locate package docker-compose-**plugin** Switch over to this guide to manually install docker with the deb files.

item.title: Hack Box
item.description: Let’s setup a new “Hack Box” for TryHackMe challenges and Capture The Flags (CTFs). Previously, I’ve always used Kali Rolling inside of VirtualBox. But let’s try and get away from Virtual Machines (VMs). Why? Mainly the boot times, slow browsing and general laggy annoyances. I want a fast, simple system without the need to boot a VM and deal with stutters. The thinking is, use Windows Subset for Linux (WSL) with headless Kali Linux.

item.title: Hack Notes
item.description: üö© A collection of notes, commands, & links to help w/ hacking & cybersec. Work in progress, please be patient while it‚Äôs updated. CyberChef // GTFOBins // HackTricks // RevShells // PayloadsAllTheThings üî• Kill Chain General CTRL + SHIFT + UP|DOWN # scroll CTRL + SHIFT C|V # Copy|Paste nl # cat w/ line nums sed # stream editor ip= # set alias env var echo $ip # test alias

item.title: Git
item.description: Just a few notes/things to remember while using git. Typical git process: git pull $link git add . git commit -m 'v0.1' git push $link Switch branches from master to main git branch -m master main

item.title: Chill Hack
item.description: Chill Hack CTF from TryHackMe, enjoy.

item.title: Opacity TryHackMe
item.description: TryHackMe’s Opacity is a ’easy’ Boot2Root room for pentesters and cybersec enthusiasts (like you!). Plus, for black friday, checkout the free giveaway bundles below.

item.title: Policies
item.description: Who we are Our website address is: https://mrash.co. What personal data we collect and why we collect it Comments When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor‚Äôs IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection. An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it.

item.title: Now
item.description: Hi, I‚Äôm Ash. I‚Äôm an IT teacher, learning cybersec, python and hacking. Goals For Focus Making weekly YouTube videos. Publishing monthly newsletters. Publishing regular blog posts. Goal 2-5k YouTube subscribers, 400-500 newsletter friends, and 1-2k monthly views/visitors. Annual Reviews 2023 2022 2021- Some Loves Slow-burn movies e.g. Whiplash, Uncut Gems and Joker. Fine wining/dining like Candian Club and Malibu. Travelling to New York, Singapore, and the Living Room. Timeline 2012-14: Studied 2016-20: Businesses 2018-21: Classroom Teacher 2022-Present: Online Teacher Thanks For Reading ‚òï I‚Äôll Buy You A Coffee

item.title: Curious
item.description: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm curious,‚Äù has become my favourite phrase to use in conversation. Curiosity is pretty awesome. It draws us to people, places and interesting things. It can influence important decisions and spark lifelong pathways. Let‚Äôs dive into curiosity more. Hi, I‚Äôm Ash, a 27 y/o cybersec enthusiast journaling my journey on productivity & hacking. You‚Äôve received a copy of the Monthly Monitor as you subscribed via the site or accessed a product.

item.title: 2022 Annual Review
item.description: Welcome to my 4th Annual Review, can you believe 2022 is over? It’s been a long 12 months, yet it‚Äôs gone so fast. Here’s my 2022 recap plus my plans for 2023. Note, if interested see 2019, 2020 and 2021. ~ Hi, my name‚Äôs Ash, I‚Äôm 27 and a cyber security enthusiast sharing my journey. You‚Äôve received this¬†newsletter¬†as you subscribed via my website or downloaded a freebie. ~

item.title: How To Fix TryHackMe VPN Not Working
item.description: Is your TryHackMe OpenVPN not working? Let‚Äôs fix it, here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll need: Some computer networking knowledge. A TryHackMe account. An OpenVPN config file via Network Access. Alright, so your there‚Äôs a few problems when trying to connect with OpenVPN to TryHackMe. Let‚Äôs cover them and learn how to fix connection problems in TryHackMe, let‚Äôs go. How Do I Use OpenVPN On TryHackMe? First you need to have an active account with an OpenVPN config file generated and downloaded to your system.

item.title: 100 Days Of Hacking
item.description: Programming, terminals, networking, and pen testing. There‚Äôs a lot to love in computer hacking. Are you learning to hack? Maybe you‚Äôve started but can‚Äôt keep motivated or you might not know where to start, let‚Äôs fix that! Here‚Äôs 100 days of hacking, a flexible learning path to keep you on track. Are you in? Yes, good, let‚Äôs go! *Disclaimer, this is designed for self-paced learning and uses multiple resources from various creators.

item.title: Crack The Hash TryHackMe Walkthrough
item.description: Let‚Äôs tackle Crack The Hash, another TryHackMe room full of hash-cracking challenges. If you‚Äôd like a video walkthrough, then see the linked video below for a full guide to Crack The Hash. Quickly, what is a hash and hashing in general? ‚ÄúHashing serves the purpose of ensuring integrity, i.e. making it so that if something is changed you can know that it‚Äôs changed. Technically, hashing takes arbitrary input and produce a fixed-length string‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äî Daniel Miessler, Hashing vs.

item.title: OverTheWire: Bandit
item.description: Bandit is a beginner Capture The Flag (CTF) game from OverTheWire (OTW). Whether you‚Äôre familiar with text-based games or have never even thought of playing them (me). This is the perfect CTF for learning Linux. You‚Äôre here to either copy my answers OR learn. Can I ask you to please focus on the learning? It‚Äôs okay to peak when you‚Äôre so blind it‚Äôs crippling you, but please don‚Äôt just copy, copy, copy!

item.title: I Won
item.description: We‚Äôve made it to October so let‚Äôs recap last month and catch up. Here‚Äôs a quick story I wanted to share with you about my first coding competition. Disclaimer, you‚Äôve received this newsletter as you subscribed to Mr Ash .co. Note, the August newsletter wasn‚Äôt published via email but is now live. I Won My First Coding Competition It‚Äôs early July and I‚Äôm scrolling Discord where I find myself on the W3Schools server.

item.title: AFK Aug
item.description: Hi friend, Are you stressed? Most people are despite the ease of modern living. What’s something we can do to combat work-life stresses? Disclaimer, you‚Äôve received this newsletter as you‚Äôve subscribed to Mr Ash.co. Note, this month has a shortened newsletter. AFK Away From Keyboard (AFK), coined by PC gamers to quickly chat ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting food, don’t kill me in game‚Äù or something similar. I still use AFK today in work meetings.

item.title: Replit EdFest 2022 Jam - Intro To PyScript
item.description: ATTENTION! If you‚Äôd like to do the course yourself, join up using this link for FREE. And don‚Äôt forget to watch the video walkthrough. Welcome to your Intro to PyScript, a simple replit that teaches you the basics of the modern Python web dev technology. You‚Äôre going to set up your own simple HTML page with a linked Python program. You‚Äôll enable PyScript, take user data, run it through your program and print it back out to the user.

item.title: Network Services 2 P3 MySQL - TryHackMe Walkthrough
item.description: Welcome back to another video. We are going to be doing Network Servicestwo, part three enumerating exploiting more commonnetwork Services and misconfigs. We‚Äôre up to task eight, nine and ten, and we‚Äôll finish off with elevenrounding out this whole thing. Cool. All right, let‚Äôs start off with taskeight, understanding MySQL. Just before I do, got to remind you, if you want a written write up,you can catch the link to that below.

item.title: Network Services 2 TryHackMe Part 2 SMTP
item.description: Welcome back. We are going to be doing the restof Network services two. And this is now part two. We‚Äôre going on to SMTP. So we‚Äôre going to be doingtasks five, six and seven. And then we‚Äôll be finishing off8910 eleven in the next video. If you want a written write up,the link will be below. And if you need anythingelse, please reach out. And if you want to like videosubscribe, do all that stuff.

item.title: CS50P Problem Set Guide
item.description: Hello, world and welcome, this is a breakdown, or guide, to the problem sets (psets) to CS50‚Äôs Introduction to Programming with Python (CS50P). If you‚Äôre unaware, CS50 Python comes from Havard which operates edx CS50. It‚Äôs a great introduction to the programming language Python. If you‚Äôre brand new to Computer Science (CS) or have a background in technology, CS50 covers the fundamentals really well. It‚Äôs one of the best places to learn Python online.

item.title: Agent Sudo TryHackMe Walkthrough
item.description: Welcome back to another TryHackMe room, the challenge today is Agent Sudo. No spoilers below within the hints, just some good ol‚Äô fashion hints to help you out on your agent sudo journey. For more detail, with some spoilers, see the steps section, and for everything I did, see my notes. If you prefer a video walkthrough, well that‚Äôs linked below, and if you want my personal thoughts on the room, check out the reflection via the video.

item.title: OhSINT Writeup TryHackMe
item.description: Let‚Äôs go for another TryHackMe room, this time we‚Äôre tackling OhSINT, which begs the question ‚Äúare you able to use open-source intelligence to solve this challenge?‚Äù This was a fun, different room for me, I love the idea of OSINT and using the web to solve challenges. Despite having a few initial issues along the way, it was fun to answer ‚Äúwhat information can you possible get with just one photo?

item.title: THM SimpleCTF Hints, Writeup and Notes
item.description: Welcome back to TryHackMe, this time it‚Äôs SimpleCTF‚Ä¶ or as I‚Äôd call it ‚ÄòNot So SimpleCTF‚Äô‚Ä¶ as I had a few issues getting this CTF to work. Let‚Äôs dive into it. Hints How many services are running under port 1000? nmap What is running on the higher port? Check the nmap scan results. What‚Äôs the CVE you‚Äôre using against the application? CVE-****-**** don‚Äôt forget to include CVE- at the beginning. To what kind of vulnerability is the application vulnerable?

item.title: Easily Learn Difficult Things: Object Orientated Programming
item.description: I’m a big fan of YouTuber Ali Abdaal, his ex-PA now turned YouTuber Elizabeth Flipis has a great channel. She creates content about herself living in London while studying Medschool. Her latest video You’re Not Stupid: How to Easily Learn Difficult Things caught my attention. As someone who feels dumb 90% of the time, this is perfect, and the timing couldn’t be better as I’m learning computer science and programming.

item.title: Automate The Boring Stuff With Python Practice Projects
item.description: Automate The Boring Stuff With Python is an incredible book, and course by Al Sweigart to learn Python coding and computer science for the everyday person. With its straightforward learning approach, and succinct program examples and explanations, it‚Äôs many hobbyists‚Äô go-to book for Python. This article breaks down my personal solutions to the practice projects outlined at the end of most chapters. As I continue to learn Python and generally computer science, I enjoy seeing how others solve coding problems.

item.title: Privacy: Why You Should Care About Data
item.description: In March 2022, some friends of mine got scammed on Instagram. A scammer posing as a friend or work colleague tricked them into ‚Äúhelping‚Äù them out and took over their account. It‚Äôs motivated me to help those I know and love by being more aware of the dangers that lurk on the internet. The reality is, that the internet is full of your personally identifiable information (PII) being leaked and publically available.

item.title: Learning HTTP Requests - A Mini HTTP Exercise
item.description: While learning HTTP in Detail, I thought it‚Äôd be fun to put it to the test in the terminal. Here‚Äôs a quick exercise to practice learning HTTP Requests, Responses and Headers. Difficulty: Easy ‚Äì new to Linux. Environment: local Debian-based Linux installation e.g. Ubuntu in VirtualBox. Commands: git, python3, cd, mkdir, wget. Steps Here‚Äôs everything you need to do, note, you‚Äôll need two terminals to do this: Terminal 1: git clone https://github.

item.title: TryHackMe Network Services 1 Part 2 Telnet
item.description: Welcome to TryHackMe Network Services Walkthrough Part 2, oh yeah! Let‚Äôs learn, then enumerate and exploit a variety of network services and misconfigurations, second up is telnet. Watch this Network Services Walkthrough for TryHackMe‚Äôs room, Part 2 Telnet. Task 5 Understanding Telnet Questions: What is Telnet? application protocol What has slowly replaced Telnet? ssh How would you connect to a Telnet server with the IP 10.10.10.3 on port 23? telnet 10.

item.title: TryHackMe Network Services 1 Part 3 FTP
item.description: Let‚Äôs go, TryHackMe Network Services Walkthrough Part 3, welcome! Step 1 learn, step 2 enumerate, and step 3 exploit‚Ä¶ but what? Well, a variety of network services and misconfigurations of course, this time it‚Äôs FTP. Watch the Network Services Walkthrough for TryHackMe‚Äôs room, Part 3 FTP. Task 8 Understanding FTP Questions: What communications model does FTP use? client-server What‚Äôs the standard FTP port? 21 How many modes of FTP connection are there?

item.title: Hackers Learning Path
item.description: Want to hack computers? But what is hacking and how do people learn it? Here‚Äôs a vetted list of resources to learn computer hacking. Starting out is hard work, so that‚Äôs why I‚Äôve put this list together, to help demystify hacking for you. The good news is anyone (including you) can learn to hack, and in even better news, it‚Äôs a lot of fun. All you need is effort and time, most of the resources are completely free.

item.title: Updating Domains with Cloudways ‚Ä¢ 301 Redirects
item.description: So you‚Äôre updating domains, but what about your search rankings? I just did this myself and it wasn‚Äôt as hard as I expected. Disclaimer, if you need help, read .htaccess file and SSH setup. HTACCESS File If you‚Äôre running a Content Delivery Network (CDN), turn off caching. For example, Cloudflare Dashboard > turn on development mode. Next, connect to your server via SSH. ssh <username>@<ip> nano .htaccess Copy the text below, replace the placeholder text.

item.title: Cowsays What CTF - A Beginner Linux Project
item.description: Want a beginner Linux CTF (Capture The Flag)? Moove over, here‚Äôs Cowsays What CTF. A simple question-based python program to test your beginner Linux level skills. This simple CTF will use Linux commands to install a program, execute it and interact with it. Cowsays What CTF is inspired by TryHackMe and OverTheWire‚Äôs Bandit. *Disclaimer, if you need help getting started with Linux, see Linux Quick Start Guide. Getting Started Before you tackle the challenge, understand the scope, here‚Äôs what you need to know:

item.title: TryHackMe Network Services Room Notes
item.description: Are you going through TryHackMe‚Äôs Network Services 1 Room? Need help taking notes? I got you covered. Here are my Network Services 1 room notes from TryHackMe, use them as much as you need! Disclaimer, this is written in shorthand format, meaning, full sentences and proper grammar are not always used. For writeups, see SMB Part 1, for help with Linux, see Quick Start Guide. SMB: Understanding, Enumerating, Exploiting Server Message Block (SMB) Protocol: client/server comms for file/printer/serial ports/others for MS Windows.

item.title: TryHackMe Nmap Walkthrough
item.description: Welcome to another TryHackeMe Walkthrough, this time the Nmap room from TryHackMe‚Äôs Beginner Learning Path. In this TryHackMe Nmap Walkthrough, we‚Äôll go over all 15 tasks and you‚Äôll see every detail you need to not only complete the Nmap room but understand it too. For a quicker look at the Nmap Room, see TryHackMe Nmap Room Notes, enjoy the TryHackMe Nmap Walkthrough, happy hacking. Disclaimer, see the video version or the previous Linux Fundamentals Part 1, Part 2, or Part 3 if needed.

item.title: TryHackMe Network Services Walkthrough SMB Part 1/3
item.description: Task 1 Get Connected Questions Ready? Let‚Äôs get going! ‚Äì No answer needed, carry on. Offline checklist to track your learning path, become a great hacker and stay on task. Task 2 Understanding SMB What does SMB stand for? ‚Äì Server Message Block What type of protocol is SMB? ‚Äì response-request What do clients connect to servers using? ‚Äì TCP/IP What systems does Samba run on? ‚Äì Unix Task 3 Enumerating SMB Run nmap scan.

item.title: TryHackMe Nmap Room Notes
item.description: Are you going through TryHackMe‚Äôs Nmap Room? Did you forget to take notes? I got you covered. Here are my Nmap room notes from TryHackMe, use them as much as you need! Disclaimer, this is written in shorthand format, meaning, full sentences and proper grammar are always not used. For a full writeup, see TryHackMe Nmap Walkthrough, for help with Linux, see Quick Start Guide. Task 1 Deploy & Task 2 Introduction Ports: allow multiple network services, ensure correct device communication, 65535 total.

item.title: Linux Fundamentals 1 - TryHackMe Walkthrough
item.description: Learning Linux? Great, me too! Here‚Äôs the Linux Fundamentals 1 Walkthrough from TryHackMe. Let‚Äôs take a look at some of the fundamentals of Linux including common commands, the terminal, your prompt and more. There‚Äôs lots to love in Linux, as there‚Äôs so many flavours or distributions, the possibilities are endless. I hope you learn something on your Linux journey! Enjoy TryHcakMe‚Äôs Linux Fundamentals 1. Disclaimer, for more TryHackMe walkthroughs, see Linux Fundamentals 2 or Linux Fundamentals 3.

item.title: Linux Fundamentals 2 - TryHackMe Walkthrough
item.description: So you‚Äôre learning Linux aye? Welcome aboard! Here‚Äôs the Linux Fundamentals 2 Walkthrough from TryHackMe. Let‚Äôs take a look at some of the fundamentals of Linux including some more commands, ssh, bash scripting and more. There‚Äôs lots to love in Linux, I hope you learn something here on your Linux journey! Enjoy TryHackMe‚Äôs Linux Fundamentals 2. Disclaimer, for more, see Linux Fundamentals 1, Linux Fundamentals 3 and Linux Quick Start Guide.

item.title: Linux Fundamentals 3 TryHackMe Walkthrough
item.description: Welcome to Linux Fundamentals 3 TryHackMe Walkthrough, the finale of the Linux Fundamental rooms on TryHackMe. Let‚Äôs learn some Linux skills and common utilities around automation, package management, and service/application logging. Are you keen? Yeah! Let‚Äôs go on with Linux Fundamentals 3 TryHackMe Walkthrough. Disclaimer, see Linux Fundamentals Part 1 and Linux Fundamentals Part 2 for more. Also, see the video walkthrough too: Task 1 Introduction & Task 2 Deploy Your Linux Machine Alright, you should be a pro with connecting to TryHackMe‚Äôs VPN via OpenVPN and ssh-ing into the TryHackMe user via the provided ip address.

item.title: CompTIA A+ Study Notes (220-1101)
item.description: Installing Hardware and Display Components Hardware and Device Replacement RAM: system memory or desk of PC, fast access, low amount = lower access speeds, volatile. Storage: file cabinet of PC, slower access, static (non-volatile). Check MoBo user guide to ensure RAM amount, form-factor etc. GPU/Video Card: processes video and connects to external monitors. CPU: brain of PC. DC Jack Replacement Research ‚Äì https://youtu.be/zFuu8LSaAQE Hard Drive Migration SSD: non-volatile flash memory for storage, faster, reliable, less power, quieter, smaller.

item.title: Basic Home Network Analysis - Beginner Cyber Sec Project
item.description: Are you a Cyber Sec student? Or just interested in the Cyber Sec space? Yes, and yes! Do you go to family and friends, hop on their network and poke around? It‚Äôs easy to do and you can quickly find vulnerabilities that someone could exploit. Recently, I stayed at my wife‚Äôs uncle and aunties house and I noticed a major network vuln. Imagine you put a lock on a door for home security but never lock it, robbers just come in every night to look around.

item.title: How To Build A PC 2023
item.description: Are you new to PC building? Maybe a friend‚Äôs put together their computer and you want to learn more. Whatever your reason, building your own PC is a lot of fun! So, let‚Äôs learn how to build a PC in 2022, this is your beginner‚Äôs guide to building a PC. Disclaimer, this is not a step-by-step article, but more of a general guide to approaching how to build a PC.

item.title: 2021 Annual Review
item.description: Here we are again, another year come and gone. Let‚Äôs look back at the lessons learned and mistakes made. All up, it‚Äôs been a big year, we‚Äôve all been redefining ‚Äònormal‚Äô post-2020. There‚Äôs been more division over the concern for safety and I genuinely hope you and your family are safe and well, thanks for reading this. Disclaimer, this is a self-indulgent article and will not be value-focused. Since 2019, I‚Äôve written yearly recaps as an exercise to be more intentional and increase personal growth.

item.title: Python Range Function ‚Ä¢ Quick Python Project Lesson
item.description: So you‚Äôre learning Python and want to understand the range function, welcome! The range function paired with a for loop is a great way to repeat code a number of times. Let‚Äôs learn the basics of the range function with Python and then it‚Äôs over to you for a little project. Basics Let‚Äôs have a simple counter go from 1 to 5, and show the results as it counts.

item.title: Homelabs 2023 Beginner's Guide To Homelabbing
item.description: You are probably new to homelabbing and need a bit of guidance. Building a homelab means building a computer network, or lab, at home. Homelabs can be anything from old laptops to expensive high-end enterprise equipment. Typically, you‚Äôll find homelabs involve a lot of virtual computers, meaning they‚Äôre not physical. There‚Äôs little entry to get started and unlimited possibility as your homelab grows. You‚Äôll find techies and sys-admins from all over the world who love to share their homelabs, projects and builds.

item.title: ZigZag - Beginner Python Project
item.description: Let‚Äôs learn some Python! Want an easy python program to get started? Here‚Äôs zigzag. This program is from Automate The Boring Stuff With Python Chapter 3, under A Short Program: Zigzag. Welcome to my third study session to learn Python Programming! The video above covers the entire process of copying the zig zag program from Automate The Boring Stuff With Python. See Built-in Functions, Time access and conversions and What does end=‚Äô ‚Äò exactly do?

item.title: Random Number Generator ‚Ä¢ Easy Python Project
item.description: Want an easy python project to get you started learning python? Here‚Äôs a random number generator built-in python! See the project live below or via GitHub. Okay, let‚Äôs build your very own number generator python program. Foundation Let‚Äôs write the program in stages. But first, it‚Äôs recommended to write out pseudo code as it helps to map out and plan the program before you deep dive into writing it.

item.title: Bagels ‚Ä¢ Beginner Python Project
item.description: Want a beginner Python Project that‚Äôs going to test you? A program longer than 40 lines of code? Look no further, here‚Äôs Bagels! This is from The Big Book of Small Python Projects ‚Äì Chapter 1 Bagels. Watch the Study Session #2 for the full programming behind the scenes. Disclaimer, some areas of this blog post are still under construction, look for Work In Progress (WIP). Global Variables, Main Function Let‚Äôs break Bagels down.

item.title: Hashing Passwords ‚Ä¢ Python Module Basics
item.description: Hashing is the foundation of tech like blockchains that make cryptocurrencies possible. See Blockchain 101 ‚Äì A Visual Demo and Blockchain 101 ‚Äì Part 2 ‚Äì Public / Private Keys and Signing. So for a fun study session, let‚Äôs follow a walkthrough on Password Hashing in Python, see the original post by DillonB07. Watch live video: 1. Update Python and Pip Update both pip and Python before starting this program.

item.title: Username Generator Beginner Python Program
item.description: Usernames, we all have one, maybe for work or on Twitter. How about a python program that automatically generates a username based on your name? Sound cool? Let‚Äôs make a simple project to generate usernames. See the live program below: Disclaimer, this is not a python tutorial, for that, see Intro To Python. Core Code Let‚Äôs get the core elements down for the username generator. First, displaying the title via print() and then using two variables with input().

item.title: Paste Text Only in Word - CTRL + SHIFT + V to Microsoft Word
item.description: Are you needing to copy/paste a lot of content from online to Microsoft Word? Yep! It seems small, but Word has the most annoying lack of a shortcut, no CTRL + SHIFT + V ‚Äì paste text only. Word has the ability to paste text only via right-click, select option. So, let‚Äôs quickly add a new shortcut to paste text only in Word. First, go to File > Options > Customize Ribbon > Keyboard shortcuts: Customize‚Ä¶

item.title: Mad Lib Game ‚Ä¢ Beginner Python Project
item.description: Are you learning Python? Need some beginner Python projects? It‚Äôs nice to have you here, this is my Mad Lib Game, an easy beginner Python Project for you! Mad Libs are a simple game, it consists of one player prompts others for a list of words to substitute for blanks in a story before reading aloud. Instead of a human, we‚Äôll have the computer read them back via the terminal, cool.

item.title: Intro To Python ‚Ä¢ Free Python Starter Guide
item.description: Wanting to learn Python? Of course you do! Python is the hacker‚Äôs language, it‚Äôs more modern than bash and it‚Äôs super cool. If you‚Äôve never programmed or wrote a line of code, that‚Äôs okay! We all have to start somewhere. There‚Äôs a lot of good places to learn Python, I recommend Automate The Boring Stuff with Python and the official Python Documentation Tutorial. If you‚Äôre learning to hack in the Cyber Security space, see Hackers Learning Path.

item.title: Vanguard vs Pearler 2023 Best Aussie FIRE Broker
item.description: Great! I just made the move. The Vanguard platform gets the job done, but Pearler has the style with more features and a clearer development roadmap. If you‚Äôre new to investing, see Beginner‚Äôs Guide To Passive Investing. Let‚Äôs look at what‚Äôs involved in switching investment brokers. Disclaimer, this is not personal financial advice. If you‚Äôd like to support the blog, consider signing up with Pearler via this link. Vanguard vs Pearler ‚Äì Why?

item.title: Guide To SEO - Ultimate Beginners Guide For SEO
item.description: Hello there Search Engine Optimisation (SEO), or in other words, changing web pages to satisfy the magical algorithm of Google. Learning SEO is a windy road that takes time, let‚Äôs go on this journey together, a guide to SEO. Nat Eliason made an SEO course and wrote how to start a blog. I‚Äôll be condensing these, plus adding my experience from web design and digital marketing. This is my beginner‚Äôs guide to SEO for blogging in 2021.

item.title: CyberWox CyberSec Homelab on Virtual Box
item.description: Homelabs are fun, challenging, but fun. Building an entire virtual network of interconnected computers to simulate real-world traffic and situations. This is my additional guide to Cyberwox‚Äôs Building a Cybersecurity Homelab, but, for those using VirtualBox. Here‚Äôs a visual guide for the lab: *Disclaimer, this does not contain 100% of the steps of this project. Intro Ideally, use a dedicated lab computer for this, a spare laptop or an old gaming PC.

item.title: Linux Quick Start Guide
item.description: Learning Linux is fun! Beginning Linux is hard. There‚Äôs a lot of free courses and content to help you. But what about a quick start guide to Linux? Getting started with Linux made easy? No fluff, just a quick and dirty setup to get you started with Linux basics! Well, here it is, the Linux Quick Start Guide. To follow along, install Ubuntu Linux and let‚Äôs learn how to get started with Linux.

item.title: Linux Unhatched Cisco Course Review and Notes
item.description: Learning Linux? Well, Linux Unhatched from CISCO Net Academy is a great place to start. Depending on your experience, this short course could take you a few days or over a week. It‚Äôs free, well structured, easy to read and interactive. Perfect for learning Linux. Below are my notes for the course, I skipped 14-14.2 as I‚Äôll be coming back to that section. *Disclaimer, the course content is owned and shared via CISCO Net Academy.

item.title: WordPress App Won't Connect To Website Cloudways Self-hosted
item.description: Your WordPress app won‚Äôt connect to your website? Let‚Äôs fix that! Note, this is for Cloudways self-hosted websites. Follow this guide if you need help setting up the app and connecting it to your website. Check Jetpack Is Installed Make sure you have the most up-to-date plugin Jetpack. It‚Äôs what connects your self-hosted site to the app. If you‚Äôve never set Jetpack up, follow this guide to help you.

item.title: Basic Python Project ‚Ä¢ Is It Raining?
item.description: Learning python? It‚Äôs an incredible programming language to have in your tool belt. This project is inspired by an early example from Automate The Boring Stuff with Python. Flow Control This python project is to impliment this flow chart: Taken from chapter 2, there‚Äôs a few things to digest, see the code step by step in Python Tutor. Let‚Äôs write the steps is psuedoe code: Ask if it‚Äôs raining? If no, go outside.

item.title: Hackers Beginner Guide To Online Anonymity
item.description: How do we start using our mad hacker skills in the real world AND remain undetected? We need to set ourselves up to be anonymous! No, we‚Äôre not joining a hacktivist group here. Let‚Äôs learn the basics to cover ourselves online. We‚Äôll be using Kali Linux in this example, here‚Äôs my guide if you need help getting set up. For a wider approach to online anonymity, see Kalle Hallden‚Äôs Become Invisible Online.

item.title: Beginner Python Project - Guessing Game
item.description: Do you want a beginner Python project to keep you on your programming journey? Here‚Äôs a breakdown of a simple Guessing Game made in Python. See it live via Replit or view the source code via GitHub. Full disclosure, this is a part of the Automate The Boring Stuff with Python Programming Course. Plan the Program with Pseudocode Pseudocode is like a programmer‚Äôs brain dump. Write out a simple list of the steps this guessing game will go through.

item.title: Kali Linux WSL WITHOUT Microsoft Store
item.description: Before you start, make sure your Windows 10 OS is up to date as version 1903 or higher can run this. To check the version, click Windows Start Button and type System Information, next to Version you‚Äôll see your current number. If lower than version 1903, go to Settings and Update to get latest changes. Okay, now you‚Äôre good to go! 1. Setup Subsystem for Linux Right click the Windows Start Button and open Windows PowerShell (Admin).

item.title: TryHackMe RootMe Walkthrough
item.description: I‚Äôm still on the Complete Beginner learning path from TryHackMe, so this is my first venture outside into their library of CTF‚Äôs. This is a beginner ‚Äòeasy‚Äô game, their description reads a CTF for beginners, can you root me? If you‚Äôre unaware, root means top-level access, like super admin or master-of-everything. When you gain root-level access, you own that machine, so install, delete, copy or whatever else you want, it‚Äôs yours.

item.title: PicoCTF General Skills
item.description: Welcome, it‚Äôs nice to have you here. My first ever write-up in the Cyber Sec space, I‚Äôm excited! Thanks to NetworkChuck‚Äôs Discord for getting me onto GynvaelEN‚Äôs Hacking Livestream #5 lead me to find PicoCTF. PicoCTF is a great place to start CTF‚Äôs, their beginner friendly options provide a simple step into the space! Disclaimer, I didn‚Äôt realise they were getting more difficult. So I couldn‚Äôt complete all the General Skills, 10/12 so far.

item.title: Starting Out In Cyber Security
item.description: Over the last few years, the term Cyber Security has become more popular. Google trends show it‚Äôs searched now more than ever before in history. It‚Äôs currently Australia‚Äôs top hiring priority. What‚Äôs Cyber Security? And why is it so popular? Let‚Äôs do some research and find out! Disclaimer: I‚Äôm not a Cyber Security expert, I‚Äôm a student of IT and love sharing what I‚Äôm learning or have learnt. What‚Äôs Cyber Security?

item.description: Setting up a Linux Operating System like Ubuntu can be a bit daunting, especially if you‚Äôre a firm Windows user with no Linux experience. I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre here starting your Linux journey! You won‚Äôt look back! Ubuntu is generally accepted as the most beginner-friendly Linux OS. Download Ubuntu and VirtualBox Go to ubuntu.com to download the iso file, it has the entire operating system compressed into it. Note the system requirements:

item.title: 2020 Annual Review
item.description: I‚Äôve been procrastinating this article. Summarising an entire year feels difficult. But I see the value in looking back. It makes moving forward clearer. Looking forward is hard. The future is a fantasy. No one knows what‚Äôs happening tomorrow. But looking back is tangible. I like tangible. So here‚Äôs my look back at the past 12 months. Ups, downs and the honesty in-between. This article is self-indulgent. If you want value, this isn‚Äôt for you.

item.title: OneNote to Notion and Moving Apps
item.description: If you‚Äôre reading this you may very well be a lot like me. Using OneNote for personal notes, jotting down key meeting highlights and organising thoughts and ideas. If that sounds familiar, you‚Äôre probably a long time user of OneNote and a happy user. Personally I‚Äôve always enjoyed using it. It‚Äôs fast, fluid design and easy navigation make it a great note-taking app. OneNote is good at one thing, notes.

item.title: 2019 Annual Review
item.description: What a year! 2019 has been busy to say the least, I‚Äôve learnt a lot of new lessons made even more mistakes! But overall, it‚Äôs been a massive year of growth so it‚Äôs all been worth it! Let‚Äôs review 2019! My Job as an IT Teacher 2019 was full of highlights like being featured in the companies blog, having short piece in a local magazine, being nominated for an educational emerging leader award and having one of our students win TAFE QLD student of the year award.

item.title: Advise n' Review
item.description: Hello friend, How has your week been? Reply and let me know what‚Äôs happened. My week has been good. More time on holidays creating content and relaxing with friends. I‚Äôve still got two weeks left before going back to work, how cool is that? This covers LinkedIn‚Äôs importance, annual reviews and advice from a life coach. Reply to give me your feedback on these topics. 1. Importance of LinkedIn If you‚Äôre not on LinkedIn, it‚Äôs worth signing up and engaging.

item.title: Align Yourself
item.description: Hello friend, How has your week been? I hope this finds you well as it’s been a busy week wrapping up classrooms and assessing student work for me! You may have noticed I’m writing again, yes that’s right, I’m sticking to good habits and moving forward! What is Business Coaching? Dan Sullivan’s Coaching: The #1 Industry For The 21st Century explains what business coaching is. I never understood business coaching, sports coaching makes sense though!

item.title: Bandit Level 10 – 14
item.description: Over The Wire‚Äôs Bandit is a Linux Capture The Flag that tests your hacking skills. In this video, we walk through Bandit levels 10 to 14. These are some of the more difficult levels, but our clear and concise explanations will help you get through them. By the end of this video, you‚Äôll be one step closer to becoming a master hacker!

item.title: Beginner's Guide To Passive Investing 2023 Income, Tax, Super, Stocks and ETFs

Let‚Äôs do a bit of research and look into investing! Disclaimer, I‚Äôm not a financial advisor, seek professional financial advice, this is for entertainment purposes only. This is primarily for Australian citizens; research your countries tax and investment-related laws respectively. Put Simply Investing is storing your cash in a different container to increase its value.

item.title: Biz Plan

Here’s my brand/business plan, and shout out to my wife for helping me, these things are hard. Hi, my name’s Ash, I’m 27 and a cyber security enthusiast sharing my journey. You‚Äôve received this newsletter as you subscribed via my website or downloaded a freebie.

item.title: Buckets

Let’s go over some areas. Filling Up Buckets It helps my brain to have broad bucket-like groups I can pool together topics. Hacking, work-life and web design will be the three focus categories for¬†blog posts. I’ve updated¬†my bio:¬†Hacking in public @¬†mrash.

item.title: Checklist
item.description: Quick guide for pentest CTFs like Boot2Roots. Wikis HackTricks AppSecExplained Red Team Notes Blogs Overgrowncarrot1 Enumerate Open ports? rustscan, nmap. Running services? Version numbers? Operating System (Linux/Windows)? Domains? /etc/hosts Webserver (Apache/Ngnix)? Subdomins? DNS nslookup $domain dig -query=ANY $domain Common Files robots.txt sitemap.xml .htaccess security.txt manifest.json browserconfig.xml etc Thanks for reading

item.title: Dilemma

Mine was slightly uneventful (like last month) and flu ridden due to colder weather. I hope yours was better. Let’s focus on a learning dilemma, an ongoing issue I and many face. How to continue a learning path when things get difficult and stale. Disclaimer, this newsletter is from Mr Ash.

Like he says, ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt you have a website? I think EVERYONE needs a website, especially if you are trying to get a job in information technology!

item.title: Lazy n Lost
item.description: Hi friend, We made it through April, I hope you‚Äôve had a good month and you‚Äôre doing well. Warning, this letter is self-indulgent so if that‚Äôs not your thing, I understand, you can read the blog posts under Months Memories below. Let‚Äôs chat, I was really lazy this month, honestly, I had a tough week or two throughout April, my brain spiralled leaving me pretty lost. So I thought it‚Äôd be beneficial to explore the habit of laziness and how it impacts me and probably you too.

item.title: Learn Cyber

CTFs are gamified learning, I mean, why do people spend so many hours playing video games?

item.title: Let's Write
item.description: Hi friend, I hope your November has been well, question, do you write a lot? Generally, most people write or type daily as it’s fundamental to their job or life. It’s also the basis of how computer programs are made so it’s sort of what the entire tech world is built on. Writing is how we share information, how we teach and provide knowledge. Let’s see how writing independently can improve our lives.

Stop reading this and go to this guide. If you’re still here, why? Spend your next 3-4 hours reading, taking notes and having your mind blown.

item.title: You Dream'n
item.description: Hey friend, Can you believe it’s the end of another month? Four weeks can go so fast! October’s been about goals, dreams, and the power of compounding habits to achieve them. Compound, claimed to be the eighth wonder of the world (it is for investing), but what is it? Put simply, compound is the long term effects of small steps. For example, going to the gym once every couple of days shows little result, but that habit compounded over years returns massive gains.
